title: life-saving-treatment-discussed-holyrood
story: Robert Baldock suffered a stroke, which dramatically changed his le, in March .At the time, he received a thrombectomy, which he told the Courier ldquosaved my le.However, he was just one of  people across the country that year to receive the treatment, which is a highly specialised procedure involving physically removing the clot that caused the stroke and opening up the blocked artery.It is most effectivedone in the first few hours after a stroke and the procedure can help prevent signicant disability from a severe stroke.Mr Baldock, , has campaigned for thrombectomies to be offered throughout the country, with Iain Gray, East Lothian MSP, backing his call.Mr Gray said: ldquoI have backed Robert and other Chest Heart  Stroke Scotland campaigners on their call to bring back thrombectomy to NHS Scotland since the campaign was launched last year.ldquoUnfortunately, despite repeated promises by Scottish Ministers, there has been very little progress on this issue and between  and  Scots a year are still missing out on the opportunity to access this le-saving treatment.Mr Grayrsquos motion received the backing of a number of fellow MSPs.Mr Baldock said a thrombectomy was his ldquoonly option.The former digital solutions designer had been visiting friends in Edinburgh but later that evening began experiencing a headache.The pain got worse until about pm when he felt he had ldquono control over my body.He said: ldquoI couldnrsquot move my arm or cry out. I went to hospital, had tests which came back negative and it was presumed I had suffered a TIA , often referred to as mini stroke as the effects only last up to  hours.ldquoI was sent home and told to call the hospital on Monday to arrange a scan. I didnrsquot get the chance.ldquoAt .am on Sunday morning I suffered and survived a serious ischaemic stroke.ldquoAll I can remember of that morning is the ambulance crew trying to manoeuvre me down the narrow stairs of the cottage with great dficulty.ldquoI couldnrsquot move or speak. A scan revealed a large clot had caused my stroke.ldquoNormally you would have a clot busting drug to dissolve the clot and restore blood flow to the brain.ldquoHowever I was told this treatment wasnrsquot going to be effective for me. My family and friends who were with me were told to prepare for the worst. Things didnrsquot look good at all!ldquoMy only option was a thrombectomy. Thankfully, I was able to have the thrombectomy that saved my le. For me there was no other alternative.Mr Baldock recently moved from Dirleton into accessible housing in North Berwick.He said: ldquoI continue to make great post-stroke progress, even two-and-a-half years after the event.Jane-Claire Judson, chief executive at Chest Heart  Stroke Scotland, said something needed to be done to ensure the treatment was freely available.She said: ldquoEvery extra month without a thrombectomy service means around  people in Scotland will be left with signicant disabilities after their stroke.ldquoIt means more families will be heartbroken and robbed of precious time with those they love.ldquoStroke patients in Scotland deserve the very best care. Peoplersquos lives are being destroyed by stroke itrsquos not good enough and there is no time to wait.Anyone looking to back the campaign can sign a petition at www.chss.org.uk thrombectomy

title: number-children-living-poverty-east-lothian-rise
story: East Lothian Council says Universal Credithas had a ldquoprofound effect on families across the county.The local authority has witnessed an increase in in-work poverty, foodbank referrals and cases being presented to childrenrsquos services since the new single benefit was introduced.A new report into Child Poverty in East Lothian reveals that the number of youngsters living in poverty increases in areas where more families are relying on the benefit.And it said that a ldquosignicant number of families were experiencing in-work poverty, which meant they needed Universal Credit payments to top up their low incomes.The report includes quotes from parents struggling to cope, with one revealing: ldquoI had no energy to walk the kids to school and it was hard to focus at work.ldquoFor the school October holiday club I had no money to give the kids for a snack.ldquoThey went and asked other children for something and I felt awful.East Lothian MP Martin Whitfield said that it was time for Universal Credit to be scrapped.He said: ldquoThis report confirmswhat many of us said would happen following the introduction of Universal Credit and the negative impact we saw as it was piloted in East Lothian."The Government refused to listen and have railroaded through this ill-conceived new system which is causing signicant hardship for many families.ldquoItrsquos time for UC to be scrapped, austerity ended and for governments to make fighting poverty a priority.The report, produced by East Lothian Council and NHS Lothian, said there was no doubt the introduction of UC, which was piloted in the county in  and replaced a range of benefits with a single payment, had an impact.Overall, an estimated  per cent of children in East Lothian are living in poverty.The report looks at child poverty across the county, with a wide gap between some communities.In North Berwick Coastal ward, it was estimated just over . per cent of children were living in poverty after housing costs were taken into account, comparedto . per cent in Musselburgh East and Carberry.It revealed that last year, East Lothian Foodbank fed , children, while nearly one in  primary school pupils was entitled to a clothing grant, with . per cent of P to S youngsters entitled to a free school meal.Demand for childrenrsquos services increased by eight per cent last year and a wide range of initiatives have been introduced and highlighted in the report, from holiday lunch clubs to community kitchens.The report said: ldquoOn average, one in five children in East Lothian is living in poverty after housing costs are taken into account in some areas this rises to one in four.ldquoEast Lothian is forecast to grow at oneof the fastest rates of all  local authorities in Scotland. The number of --year-olds is projected to increase by . per cent between  and .Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet spokesperson for childrenrsquos services said: ldquoIt is shameful that in this day and age there are one in five children in East Lothian living in poverty.ldquoToo many local children are growing up in homes without enough food, the ability to take part in activities or the living conditions and amenities which are the norm for most households in st-century Scotland.ldquoThis report underlines the vital importance of properly funding local public services to support children and families in poverty.Iain Gray, East Lothian MSP, said the statistics were ldquoshocking.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoThe introduction of Universal Credit has had a profound effect on the finances of many East Lothian households.ldquoWe have seen the impacts across a number of council and partner services ndash a rise in presentations to childrenrsquos services, an increase in rent arrears, more referrals being made to East Lothian Foodbank, and greater levels of in-work poverty.ldquoAll of these measures point to a correlation between the introduction of Universal Credit and an increase in levels of poverty, and child poverty in particular.ldquoWe are working across our area with partners including the voluntary sector to raise awareness of the issues and challenges our communities face, and to find ways to support and address them.ldquoThis includes funding for projects through our area partnerships to tackle poverty and inequalities, encouraging take-up of free school meals, changing the criteria for school unorm allowance to widen access, and raising awareness of national initiatives such as the Scottish Governmentrsquos Best Start grants.A UK Government spokesperson said: ldquoTackling poverty will always be a priority for this Government. Absolute poverty is lower than it was in : there are more people in work than ever before, and wages continue to outpace inflation.ldquoBut we know some families need more support, which is why we continue to spend pound billion a year on working-age benefits.ldquoWith Universal Credit, people can get paid urgentlythey need it and wersquove changed the system so people can receive even more money in the first two weeks than under the old system.ldquoMeanwhile, Scotland has signicant welfare powers, including flexibilities within Universal Credit and the power to top-up existing benefits, pay discretionary payments and create entirely new benefits altogether.

title: Rosemary Goring  If we want to end sectarianism  we must abolish Catholic schools
story: Glasgow Councilrsquos ban on a number of Loyalist and Republican marches and parades in the city last weekend led not to an outbreak of peace, as had been hoped, but to an angry demonstration in George Square.According to Tom Wood, former Deputy Chief Constable of Lothian and Borders police, the scenes of vocerous protest were reminiscent of the gilets jaunes in France, or recent pro-democracy clashes with police in Hong Kong. Wood denounced the councilrsquos decision to block the parades as ldquostupid. This seems harsh, although the immediate backlash does show this cautionary step backfired. As Wood commented in a newspaper article, outright bans simply allow resentment to fester and violence to erupt where.Explosions of sectarian aggression and abuse are an obvious outrage, but even entirely peaceful religious marches through Glasgow are a blot on the cityrsquos reputation. Whenever a Grand Orange Lodge goes past, banging drums, playing flutes and waving banners, I feel I have stepped back three centuries. In theory, Orange marches are harmless and legitimate expressions of faith and historical commemoration. In practice, in the west of the country at least, they are the unlit end of a fuse that doesnrsquot take much to ignite. Everyone knows these are potentially inflammatory occasions, and a marching season that passes without incident is the very definition of a miracle.As is all too evident, sectarian prejudice is alive and well. Those who say it is nearly extinct are either optimists or judge todayrsquos level of confrontation against a much bloodier and more ignorant past. By that measure, certainly, things are considerably better than they were even as recently as when I joined this newspaper when on my first day a new colleague commented on the arrival of yet another Protestant. Anti-discrimination laws have helped promote more enlightened attitudes, but even without this statutory inducement to scrupulous fairness, the majority of us these days make no distinction between Catholic and Protestant,indeed we even notice it at all.:Faith no more  Have catholic schools had their day, asks Kevin McKennaThe country has come a long way since the Church of Scotlandrsquos disgraceful and virulent anti-Catholicism in the s, and the barefaced discrimination and hurtful jibes Catholics of all ranks endured. No wonder separate schools were considered necessary. Yet while levels of abuse and discrimination are dramatically lower than before, in some quarters hoary old grievances and antediluvian attitudes continue to smoulder.You could argue that the answer is education: an ongoing challenging of closed minds that will eventually lead to a state where nobody cares what religion other people follow. It is Tom Woodrsquos contention, however, that in order to eradicate sectarianism we need to abolish Catholic schools. These, he believes, are the root of the problem.With some reluctance, I have to agree their time is up. This, despite knowing that endorsing this view would appear to be rejecting the liberal values that I consider essential for a fair and well-run country. If parents wish to send their children to a school whose principles are guided by the Catholic faith ndash or any other for that matter ndash surely they should be allowed that choice  By all accounts, the education students receive in Catholic schools is impressive, and in some cases so enviable that lapsed members of the church appear to have a Damascene reawakening in order to get their offspring into the classroom.Yet the existence of this archaic system of schooling is tangible evidence of a problem that refuses to wither. From early childhood, separate schools reinforce the idea of dference, segregation and distinction. Whatever side of that school fence you walk, you are made aware from Primary One onwards of the concept of Them and Us.Therersquos another distasteful aspect of segregated schools too. Richard Dawkinsrsquos new book, Outgrowing God, which is aimed at young readers, tries to help ldquobreak the cycle of indoctrination. That word will be offensive to those who think they are doing their best by their children in instructing them in their own religious beliefs and culture, be they Catholic, Protestant, Muslim or Jew. But, even when done with the best intentions, sending a child to a school affiliated to a church is a form of intellectual and emotional programming. It represents the opposite of liberal values.:Catholic schools are rated higher by inspectorsFor as long as it is possible to put a child through a denominational education, society is tacitly acknowledging the power of religion to define who people are. In an age when the state is increasingly non-religious in its decision-making, in order to maintain strict neutrality and equality, it makes no sense. When single-sex institutions are frowned upon as out-dated, when discrimination based on ethnicity, background or sexual orientation is considered abhorrent, it seems odd that this particular expression of dference is allowed to continue. Onlysectarianism were unheard of, rather than a persistent blight, would it ndash just about ndash be acceptable.Back in the real world, the existence of educational pigeon-holes like these means there is little hope of religious bigotry being eradicated. Those on either side of the school gates live in an environment that allows this shameful stain on our country to persist, and even flourish. Initiatives to raise awareness or to banish deep-rooted prejudices can never be wholly successful so long as the public statement of religious identity is allowed such a state-sanctioned .This is not to attack faith itself. What iniduals choose to believe, and the ways in which they introduce children to their religion or creed at home, is their business. Nor should schools cease to teach pupils about world religions, or to help them understand the huge cultural influence that Christianity, both Catholic and Protestant, has exerted on countless aspects of our lives, for good and ill.Complete integration, however, should be the goal. The building blocks of society must mirror the kind of world we want future generations to inherit. No matter how you look at it, denominational schools have become an anomaly. If sectarianism is to become a thing of the past, then so should they.

title: scotlands-economy-brink-recession
story: Official figures found Scottish GDP fell by . per cent in the second quarter of the year.Two consecutive quarters of negative growth is the technical definition of a recession.SNP Finance Secretary Derek Mackay blamed Brexit.The UK economy shrank by .% over the same period.Over the year to June, Scottish GDP grew by just .% compared to .% for the UK.A key factor in the latest figures was a see-sawing of business activity on either side of the original Brexit deadline of March .In the quarter ahead of the date, many firms stockpiled goods in case of no-deal, with the increased economic activity lting GDP.After the deadline was extended, that process went into reverse as firms ran down their stocks and economic activity sagged."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Countdown to Brexit:  days until Britain leaves the EU","description": "Countdown to Brexit:  days until Britain leaves the EU","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media sfpYlAw poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests sfpYlAw.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": A fallback in food and draink and pharmaceutical industries, which helped drive the .% rise in Scottish GDP in the first quarter, accounted for the whole .% fall in the second.Mr Mackay said: ldquoGiven the repeated warnings from business organisations and the contraction across the UK in the same quarter, it is unsurprising but deeply frustrating that we are now seeing the Brexit impact on the Scottish economy."The responsibility for this contraction lies entirely with the UK Government.ldquoWe are already taking steps to protect jobs and our economy from Brexit but not every impact can be mitigated. We will continue to stand firm against efforts to take us out of the EU against our will.On a visit to the Codebase technolgy incubator in Edinburgh, Mr Mackay added:ldquoIt is worrying news, but I do believe it is the consequence of the Brexit threat.Askedhe was concerned about the prospect of a recession, he said: ldquoYes, I am."All the economic consensus is, and this is a further warning shot, that this contraction for Quarter  is a concern and the economic consensus is thattherersquos any form of Brexit there will be a negative economic impact."Butthere is a no-deal Brexit, then I feel itrsquos now a certainty there will be a recession.Asked about independence causing even more uncertainty, he said: ldquoWersquove been able to show how independence can help us grow our economy, have a more prosperous and fairer society. Wersquove shown the dference independence would make.ldquoIt would give us the abilities that small independent countries around the world have to react to events and grow their economies, and be more agile and resilient.Scottish Secretary Alister Jack said: ldquoldquoI am concerned the Scottish economy has shrunk over the last quarter and continues to lag behind UK-wide figures.ldquoComing on the back of disappointing unemployment figures, more needs to be done to boost our economy and close the gap.ldquoWe will continue to work with the Scottish Government to boost the Scottish economy and create jobs. To date, the UK Government has committed pound.bn in city and growth deals and we will seize all of the opportunities that will arise once we leave the EU.ldquoI urge the Scottish Government to use the considerable powers at their disposal to improve the Scottish economy rather than holding it back with threats of a second independence referendum and the decision to make Scotland the most highly taxed part of the UK.Professor Graeme Roy from the Fraser of Allander Institute said: ldquoThe data today confirm that, like the UK as a whole, the Scottish economy contracted in the second quarter of .ldquoEconomic activity has proven particularly volatile this year as Brexit uncertainty has affected the pattern of business activity.ldquoIn the first three months of the year we saw activity boosted by firms stockpiling supplies in the event that the UK exited the EU at the end of March.ldquoWhen this did not come to pass, and the next deadline was pushed to October , we saw firms run down these stockpiles leading to lower levels of activity.ldquoThis was most clearly evident in activity in the production sectors of the economy. We saw this in the UK wide data, and we see this in the data released this morning for Scotland.ldquoIn manufacturing for example, output grew by +.% in Q, only to be followed by a contraction of -.% in Q.ldquoThe early evidence suggests that activity in the UK economy has picked up in recent months. Whilst fragile, this suggests that a technical recession ndash i.e. two consecutive quarters of falling output ndash appears unlikely.ldquoOf course, all this could changethe Brexit process was to further unravel.ldquoAs always, we urge people to focus on longer term growth rather than inidual quarter to quarter fluctuations. Over the last year growth was +.%, far from Scotlandrsquos long-term average growth rate, and lagging the UK over the same period where growth was +.%.Scottish LibDem leader Willie Rennie said: ldquoThe impact of Brexit is hitting investment, jobs and living standards, and the main phase hasnrsquot even happened yet. That is why the Lib Dems are right to offer people a way to make it stop, with our revoke policy.Economist John McLaren of Scottish Trends added: ldquoLike the UK, Scotlandrsquos economy has performed poorly in the second quarter of . This was largely down to a reversal of the, stockpiling related, fast growth seen in Manufacturing in Q.ldquoLooking at Scotlandrsquos performance over a longer timeframe and across sectors suggests that the Manufacturing sector has performed relatively well over the past decade. However, Distribution services and Business services have shown a worrying underperformance over the past  to  years.ldquoIn addition, the Health and Social Work sector, despite signicant boosts to the NHS budget, has seen falling outputsince , in contrast to most other parts of the UK. Such a contraction highlights concerns over falling Scottish productivity in this sector.Scottish Labour MP Ian Murray, on behalf of the Best for Britain campaign, said: ldquoConstitutional upheaval is causing economic turmoil in Scotland and across the UK."If we crash out of the EU without a deal then the economic damage will be considerably more severe."These figures relate to peoples livelihoods - jobs and incomes. Thats what Boris Johnson is gambling with."The threat to the Union is also causing unnecessary economic uncertainty."We need a final say on Brexit with the chance to grow the Scottish and British economies and the opportunity for the UK to remain in the EU."Andrew McRae, of the Federation of Small Businesses, said the figures were ldquodishearteningunsurprising.He said: ldquoAcross the country, firms are either pouring resources into Brexit planning or postponing critical decisions until our political leaders get their act together. That means that theyrsquore not using every tool at their disposal to create jobs and drive growth.ldquoThe small business priority is to avoid a no-deal, no-transition Brexit in just a few short weeks. Where possible, every business leader needs to take action to mitigate the risk of this chaotic outcome.ldquoBut therersquos no way such a scenario wouldnrsquot squeeze many operators. It must be avoided.ldquoNorth of the border, Holyrood decision-makers need to take note of the storm clouds on the horizon. The upcoming Scottish Government budget must focus on providing much needed stability and at every turn Ministers need to think twice about putting additional burdens on local firms.

title: tv-review-papers-reveal-people-resolute-determination-journalism-matters
story: The PapersBBCFour starsPaul EnglishLETrsquoS go for full disclosure. Although a regular contributor to The Heraldrsquos pages, Irsquove yet to set foot on the paperrsquos current editorial floor for a single day of a two-decade career. Of all the perks and pitfalls the solo flight of freelance journalism brings, one is a degree of objective perspective. In other words, I was as curious as you as to what goes on inside the office at the paper, and its stablemates.My words and stories are delivered by email. Therersquos an army of us out here, not as small as it used to be, honing our bit from kitchen tables and hogging spaces in coffee shops. More of us outside than in, it would seem ndash at times the flies on the wall in this fly-on-the-wall seemed to outnumber the journalists.The documentary began in , around the closure of the Sunday Herald newspaper, and the bold inception of two new ones ndash the Herald on Sunday and the Sunday National. Filmmaker Sarah Howitt must have been one of the few people glad to be there during a period of turbulence.Yet, while the viewer saw an ambitious new media venture, those who know the dark realities of modern newspapers could smell the gunpowder. Look there, just in the back of the shot. See the casualties of balanced budgets shuffling off down Renfield Streethellip The downturn in papers was acknowledged, and a senior editorial meeting left viewers and readers in no doubt about how todayrsquos executive newspapermen ndash and in most papers itrsquos still men ndash see the digital versus print conundrum playing out.Howitt did well to eke some subtle, telling character quirks out of those whose job is often to do the same themselves. Therersquos Richard, the Sunday National editor in Marlon Brandorsquos biker jacket. Kathleen, the political reporter without a smartphone, a mind yet to be addled by the compulsion to scroll. Kirsty, taking pictures in the rain for  years. Andy, assistant editor, always missing the bus.Wersquove yet to see the political dference between the papers laid bare, or the valiant battle mounted by the Evening Times, once the le and soul of Glasgow, against free newspapers and robust digital competition. Nor have we yet been privy to the harsh conversations about inidual futures, which take place behind closed doors.Yet despite the sense of inevitability, what The Papers revealed was a people resolute in their determination that their work mattered. And as one of their number, I offer a defiant cheer from the coffee shop.This is the second such documentary from BBC Scotland following rsquos The Paper Thistle, about The Scotsman. Editors of Scotlandrsquos other leading dailies must now justiably be wondering when they get their go on the telly in these days of dwindling newspaper sales.My first job in papers was delivering The Herald to the posh houses in Kilmacolm as a  year old. My first proper byline was as a student in The Evening Times. As David Leask put it, therersquos ink inside the veins, and one scene more than any other caught the breath.It was the sight of print presses in full flight, winged rollercoasters of ink on page, the collective endeavour of those whose place is to report, reflect, provoke, illuminate, inform, chronicle and entertain.Whatever  this documentary achieves, letrsquos hope itrsquos an appreciation of the value, importance and future of what we do. Yoursquore holding it your hands.

title: msps-move-shut-scottish-government-39-spin-39-economy
story: The Scottish Parliamentrsquos economy committee wants to end privileged ldquopre-release access for ministers and special advisers, thereby aligning the Scottish system with the UK one.At present, Scottish ministers can see Scottish economic growth and retail sales index data up to five days before they are made public.:Scotlands economy is on the brink of a recessionIn June, the committee said by a majority - with all SNP MSPs opposed - that early access should end entirely for both data sets, and access to other economic data be cut to one day.The intention is to stop ministers working up ldquospin operations to put the most positive gloss on potentially embarrassing numbers, and so frame their reporting in the media.The practice of early access to data for UK Government ministers has not been used by either the Bank of England or the Office for National Statistics since .The economy committee will today propose a Bill at Holyrood to follow suit.The move is supported by all opposition parties in Holyrood, and so should become law.Scottish Labour MSP Jackie Baillie said: ldquoFor too long SNP ministers have got away with trying to bend statistics to suit their narrow political agenda.ldquoThe excellent work of the countryrsquos leading statisticians is being weaponised by the SNP before they have even published.ldquoThis Bill will seek to put a stop to that and bring the SNP government into line with best practice on statistical publications around the UK.ldquoThe fact that the SNP was the only party not supporting the Bill in Committee tells its own story.Green Andy Wightman MSP said: ldquoThe committee has taken evidence from a series of experts who expressed their concern about the privileged access to statistics that Scottish Ministers continue to enjoy.:David Cameron secretly asked the Queen to back the Union in the  Scottish independence campaign"This flies in the face of statistical best practice. In light of the Governmentrsquos intransigence on the issue, the Committee chose to bring forward proposals for legislation to increase transparency and public trust in official statistics.A Scottish LibDem spokesperson added: ldquoToo often it seems that the government has just used the extra time to find some spin to put on the numbers.A Scottish Government spokesperson said: ldquoPre-release access is consistent with the Code of Practice for Statistics which states that it should be in line with the rules and principles set out in legislation. Indeed, UK Government Departments provide pre-release access to their statistics in a similar way to the Scottish Government.ldquoPre-release access is a matter for the Chief Statistician and the independence of his role is crucial. Any proposal to curtail access would cut across his ability to ensure the key figures about Scotland are properly communicated and understood.

title: david-cameron-secretly-39-begged-39-queen-back-union-2014-scottish-independence-campaign
story: The former Prime Minister made the highly unconstitutional move ndash to involve the head of state in a political campaign - while staying at Balmoral Castle during a tense weekend when a poll put the Yes campaign ahead for the first time.In a BBC documentary about his time in office, Mr Cameron admitted the snapshot in a Sunday newspaper just  days before the historic vote was ldquolike a blow to the solar plexus and led to a ldquomounting sense of panic that this could go the wrong way.He tells the programme: ldquoI remember conversations I had with my Private Secretary and he had with the Queenrsquos Private Secretary and I had with the Queenrsquos Private Secretary, not asking for anything that would be in any way improper or unconstitutional but just a raising of the eyebrow even you know, a quarter of an inch, we thought would make a dference.: lsquoMother of parliaments closed by the father of liesrsquo court toldA few days later, the Queen famously told a well-wisher outside nearby Craithie Kirk that she hoped ldquopeople would think very carefully about the future regarded at the time and since as Her Majesty urging Scots to stick with the Union.In an interview at the weekend about his autobiography, For The Record, Mr Cameron said how he had been ldquodelighted by the Queenrsquos intervention.He tells the BBC documentary: ldquoIt was certainly well covered [by the media], although the words were very limited. It helped to put a slightly dferent perception on things.Shortly after the referendum result on September  , the ex-PM was caught on a TV camera during a visit to New York, telling Michael Bloomberg, the then cityrsquos mayor, how Her Majesty had ldquopurred down the line when he informed of the referendum result.Mr Cameron later apologised to the Queen, admitting he had felt ldquoextremely sorry and very embarrassed for confirming she had wanted Scotland to remain in the UK.Todayrsquos bombshell revelation comes in the week that marks the fth anniversary of the referendum result - when Scots backed maintaining the -year-old Union by  per cent to  per cent - and when the UK Supreme Court deliberates on whether Prime Minister Boris Johnsonrsquos decision to suspend Parliament for five weeks was lawful and which many politicians protested had dragged the Queen into politics.Last night, Alex Salmond, the former First Minister, said: ldquoBegging a constitutional monarch to make a political intervention is not only totally improper but an indication of how desperate Prime Minister Cameron was in the final stages of the Scottish referendum campaign.ldquoScotland should always remember that Westminster does not recognise any political rule book, declared the ex-party leader.He added: ldquoCameron started the campaign uber-confident and ended up in a blue funk. I doubt If Scotland will let the Establishment off the hook next time around.The SNP declined to comment but a senior source said: ldquoWe have tried not to drag the Queen into political things others may or may not do.A spokeswoman for the Queen told The Herald: ldquoItrsquos not something we are commenting on at all.Mr Cameronrsquos highly controversial admission does not appear in tonightrsquos first instalment of The Cameron Years on BBC  at pm, "A Huge Fight on My Hands," but in the second part of the programme, ldquoThe Best is Yet to Come, broadcast next week.In his memoirs, For The Record, Mr Cameron recalled the tense run-in to the independence vote and his stay at Balmoral when at a hillside barbecue members of the Royal Family ldquogingerly asked questions but knew they shouldnrsquot express too strong an opinion.The next morning, conversation turned to the opinion poll. ldquoI tried to reassure them about lsquorogue pollsrsquo but I was struggling to convince myself, let alone them, wrote the former PM.Mr Cameron, whose late father Ian was from Aberdeenshire, made clear that he would not have resignedhe had been the prime minister to lose the -year-old Union but noted how he felt ldquo I were the one who precipitated the end of our island story, it would hurt beyond belief.: Johnson given two-week deadline to produce UKs backstop alternative or "its over," warns EU leaderIn tonightrsquos programme, George Osborne, the former Chancellor, reveals the depth of his opposition to Mr Cameron calling another referendum on Britainrsquos membership of the EU.He says he is ldquovery sorry for what happened and admits he feels ldquoresponsible because of his role at the Treasury, adding that ldquowe held a referendum we should never have held and the ldquoconsequences for the country are grave.He openly criticises the former PMrsquos approach saying: ldquoDavid Cameron was just one of a number of British Prime Ministers who had fed this idea that we were dferent than Europe, that Brussels was to blame and that the public ultimately had to have a say, and wersquove all paid a price for it.Mr Osborne, now the editor of the London Evening Standard, points out the ldquoonly thing I can plea in my mitigation ishellipI made the case against it but it wasnrsquot heard.Mr Cameron and his then Chancellor also speak openly about the fraught conversations they had in the Downing St flat, trying to convince their then friend and colleague Michael Gove to come down on their side for Remain.The Cabinet Office Minister, who became a leading figure in the Leave campaign, explains how he felt ldquosome of the conversations we had were attempts on his part[Mr Cameronrsquos] to reassure himself that our friendship would mean that I wouldnrsquot stray from the fold.The Scot goes on: ldquoDavid understandably felt that since Irsquod been prepared to knuckle under on a number of occasions beforehand and put my own feelings to one side in order to serve the team, that on this occasion, that I would do the same.Mr Cameron, who has branded Mr Gove a disloyal liar, describes as a ldquobombshell the moment when he confirmed that he would support the Leave campaign.Mr Osborne recalls the moment he warned his former Cabinet colleague, telling him: ldquoIf you go to the Leave campaign, you will destroy this Governmentwe lose this referendum, David Cameron will have to go, therersquos no way hersquoll be able to survive, and everything wersquove worked on will fall apart.

Reader David Zacks worked as a trader in that illustrious Glasgow emporium, where he recalls a bloke in a neighbouring stall selling what he boasted were genuine rolled-gold watches. After his initial pitch, however, this bold entrepreneur would add in hushed tones unheard by customers: ldquoThe gold rolled on and it rolled off again.Shower sceneDAVID Tennant, whose Netflix drama Criminal is downloadable tomorrow, has an excitable fanbase. title: letters-seek-maintain-diverse-pluralistic-education-system
story: ldquoComplete integration, however, should be the goal, she claims, conspicuously failing to offer a shred of empirical evidence to prove this would resolve or change anything. North of Dundee, there are no Catholic high schools and very few primary ones, likewise in the Borders, there is effectively ldquocomplete integration in education. Yet anti-Catholic hate crimes are still committed in these areas in flagrant contradiction of her abolitionist panacea.It is of course, complete tolerance that should be the goal together with a willingness to accept that a plural society should have a erse and pluralistic education system. Perhaps those who attack Catholic schools should reveal their true motivation they might admit that they loathe religion in general, Christianity in particular and the Catholic manestation of Christianity most especially.They might also admit that atheist or humanist parents who indoctrinate their children in accordance with the Gospel of Richard Dawkins are imposing upon them a belief system or dogma which brooks no counter or challenge, and which considers itself to be truer, purer and altogether more enlightened than any religious system of belief and infuses its adherents with a zeal to convert non-believers by law or by force.Dawkins or Ms Goring can no more disprove the existence of God than I can prove it. They have no stronger claim to veracity for their belief system than I have for mine. The dference between us is that I respect theirs and do not wish to impose conformity with mine upon them. It is in this crucial distinction that we see why atheism inevitably becomes tyrannical.Ironically, the conflict between a small number of marchers on a few Glasgow streets recently is of course political not religious. Although irrelevant to the existence of Catholic schools, it is as depressing as it is instructive to see the flames of those conflicts being fanned by some who would use them as a stick to beat Catholic schools with.Peter Kearney, Director, Catholic Media Office, Glasgow G.IT is most unfortunate that Rosemary Goring takes the view that Catholic schools must be abolished.The secular agenda in Scotland is that faith not be taught as true but as a matter for relative study. The insistence is that faith be excluded from the schools criteria for employment and admission, something which would have the effect of destroying the much-vaunted "Catholic ethos".Schools are an extension of the family and the community, not the state. Education is about the formation of habits and virtues it cannot exclude the religious dimension. Serving the most disadvantaged and underprivileged has always been central to the mission of Catholic education ndash Catholic schools are the most ethnically erse and international of all maintained schools. Catholic schools are oases of ersity and tolerance they instil a strong ethos of service to wider society and the sense of identity and belonging which independent inspectors consistently applaud in them is what leads to broad-minded citizens.Martin Conroy, Cockburnspath.ROSEMARY Goringrsquos journalese is deeply flawed. The diminution of active living Christian faith and practice by using the sociological category "religion" renders her arguments invalid. She would not write about politics without distinguishing the philosophies of the political parties who constitute our democracy.Richard Dawkins is himself an exemplar of indoctrination and is well recognised as a shallow and pejorative commentator on religion.Irish Catholic immigrants were ordered by the hierarchy not to integrate with Protestants. Now there are many marriages between Protestants and Catholics in the west of Scotland. Not everyone is at each otherrsquos throats even though the Catholic Church continues to discriminate against Protestant members of these families by refusing to recognise us as equals in Christian Faith.Rev Dr Robert Anderson, Dundonald.IT is naive to view Catholic schools as sectarian and other schools as neutral.Every school,it is to address questions of value, meaning and purpose, must do so from a particular philosophy. Failure to address these issues leaves education dry and barren.Catholic schools present a belief system and le philosophy that pupils can ultimately embrace or reject, but they know that they are being educated in a Catholic context.Meanwhile, most other schools induct pupils into a left-leaning liberal secular humanist progressive therapeutic feminist environmentalist LGBT-activist ldquosocial justice philosophy that happens to be remarkably similar to that of the Government. These pupils are usually unaware that they are being educated according to a particular philosophy.The key feature of Catholic schools is the offering of a distinct ethos that appeals to many parents and pupils, and yields better outcomes than the Governmentrsquos educational ideology. The Government is trying to squeeze Catholic schools into its own failed mould, but many of their distinctives have survived so far.Rosemary Goring overlooks all of this and focuses on the alleged contribution Catholic education makes to the bizarre tribalism known as sectarianism. But the answer to irrational hostilities is not to deprive families of the option to have their children educated according to their own values ndash values that have no place for mindless tribalism.Richard Lucas, Leader of The Scottish Family Party, Glasgow G.THOUGH the heading on Rosemary Gorings article is contentious and somewhat simplistic, she nevertheless offers relevant and tangible evidence for the ending of denominational education in Scotland.The origins of Ms Goringss report emanate from a recent newspaper article by Tom Wood, former Deputy Chief Constable of Lothian and Borders Police wherein he contends that Catholic schools need to be abolished to eradicate sectarianism. Mr Wood carelessly dismisses the origins of the sectarian ide in Scotland as fundamentally an Irish problem that was transported to Scotland in the th century and infers an equal responsibility for the perpetuation of the issue throughout the next century. This is far from the truth. Catholics in Scotland suffered from widespread institutionalised discrimination in employment, housing, education and in most walks of Scottish le until more recent times.At the opening of St Modans High School in Stirling in , a school I was proud to attend both as a pupil and as a teacher, JL Foxworthy, the redoubtable headteacher, addressed his audience of young people and parents with the hope that the school could produce future lawyers, doctors and teachers. It was his sincere wish that the Catholic community could integrate itself into Scottish le and gain acceptance in a society where prejudice remained commonplace, through their roles in middle class professions. As Ms Goring observes, separate schools were considered necessary at this time as they were the only vehicle for Catholic advancement in existence in an intolerant and prejudiced Scotland. This rationale is now, however, largely redundant.In an increasingly secular age, Catholic schools and the Orange Order have one thing in common ndash they appear archaic, isive and cling to an image of Scotland that has all but disappeared into the mists of time. It is dficult to argue, as Ms Goring rightly states, that st century Catholic schools are an obstacle to complete integration and that denominational schools have become an anomaly. The Catholic Churchs ambiguous teachings on LGBT rights, same-sex marriage and the continuation of the inequitable and antiquated approval system which vets applicants for posts in Catholic schools to determine their religious suitability are not sustainable in a liberal and inclusive Scottish society. It is time to try and see the bigger picture through the prism of future generations. It is time for the phasing out of Catholic schools in Scotland.Owen Kelly, Stirling.Evidence suggests prejudice and bias are learned rather than being innate and I agree with Rosemary Goring that therefore denominational schools have no place in todayrsquos society. I would go further as I see no place in our schools for any form of religious education. However in the absence of sectarianism I guarantee some zealots would still vent their collective spleen at a minority over some other perceived dference. ldquoBloody vegans coming over here refusing to eat haggis itrsquos an insult to Burns our heritage. Build a wall, send them back to Vega they are not the same as us, stone them!Ms Goring does of course ignore the ldquoelephant in the room of private education as the problems it causes by reinforcing societal isions and the preferentially enhancing future le-prospects of their alumni is far more destructive than religious bigotry.However, currently there is as much chance of removing religious education from schools as there is of ending private education, as it suits the Establishment that they exist and as long as we are fighting amongst ourselves we pose no threat to them.David J Crawford, Glasgow G.Read more: Rosemary Goring: If we want to end sectarianism, we must abolish Catholic schools

title: brian-beacom-soap-television-diluting-impact-nonsense
story: We all took readily to Brookside and its Scouse scallies and great writing by Jimmy McGovern. And the Australian soaps brought sunshine into our dim electric-lit living rooms. But wersquore bored with soap, . Itrsquos going down the plughole, says BBC Radio  presenter Mark Lawson. The one-time soap fan claims the genre now faces ldquopotentially fatal crises.Is he right  Viewing figures support the argument. EastEnders once pulled in  million for an episode. . But in June this year it attracted just under  million. Coronation Street now pulls in just over  million, being beaten by Emmerdale.So why are we switching off soaps  Lawson points to ldquoa fundamental creative problem in which story arcs are becoming impossible to either write or act. Hersquos dead right. When Coronation Street entered our lives in  it was so reflective of northern le that creator Tony Warren could have been holding a mirror up in a street in his native Salford. It was kitchen sink film-sensibility condensed into half an hour a week. Shot through a hairnet and a camera lens smeared with milk stout foam it told real tales of petty jealousies, wide boys and debates on social mores such as female promiscuity. ldquoThat Elsie Tanner is a tart.Nowadays, Corrie is rarely without a murder victim. Indeed, you are four times more likely to be murdered in Weatherfield than you are in Los Cabos, the Mexican city famed for drug gang killings. Up to last year,  characters have been killed in Corrie,  had heart attacks,  died in an accident and eight suffered bizarre deaths. Even teen angst soap Hollyoaks has featured more than  murders in a -year period.Lawson references Gillian Taylforthrsquos EastEndersrsquo character Kathy Beale who has suffered ldquodomestic abuse, forced adoption, fraud, car crashes, cancers, organ transplant and faked death. And she has a greedy boy whorsquos put on far too much weight. The poor woman.Itrsquos all too much. Andviewers want murder and mayhem they can turn to the likes of Line of Duty or Netflix hits such as Ozark, which contain elements of melodrama. If they want smaller television, with personal, clever conflict dialogue they can turn to the likes of Nick Hornbyrsquos State of the Union Andthey want to wallow in relationship disasters who needs the melodrama surrounding Corriersquos ditsy cancer-stricken sewing machinist Sinead, or Andrea and Grahamrsquos Emmerdale traumas when you can thrill to real-le deceit, subterfuge, pettiness and crushed egos  Love Island is now the go-to destination for heartbreak.When a partner reveals desperation we come to love them less. Itrsquos the same with soaps. When Corrie brings in Gandalf in the form of Ian McKellen to line up against Audrey Roberts the writing is on the wall. Lorraine Kellyrsquos arrival should have been reported to the Manchester Constabulary, for crimes against acting. And when Boris Johnson appeared in the Queen Vic, Danny Dyer should have given him a slap.Soap needs to be real. River City manages that fairly consistently ndash with around k viewers a week ndash although it was for too long murder crime dependent.But there is another reason why we are washing our hands of soap telly. Rival television such as Newsnight. You donrsquot think so  Tune in to most episodes and yoursquoll see tearful Speakers being manhandled, crowds screaming blue murder and shots of London streets featuring zombie figures running around, making muffled sounds about a zombie parliament. The stars of the show are also instantly recognisable: the grey-bearded man who looks like a retired geography teacher being ignored by everyone, the younger man with blond hair thatrsquos on backwards who has the swagger of a Latin American dictator and loves reciting the Iliad in ancient Greek. Tonightrsquos episode will feature  courtroom judges staring intently at documents. It will cut to Holyrood revealing a room full of anxious faces, all with fingers tightly crossed. Each face suggesting a very dferent dream.Who needs soap at all

title: nicola-love-greta-tells-congress-youre-not-trying-hard-enough
story: It seemed like an odd sentiment. The -year-old is the one who kickstarted environmental activism on its current scale and, over the course of the past year, has assumed a celebrity-like status, lecturing world leaders about the climate crisis.But Greta is acutely aware that, while better versed in global environmental policy than you or I, she is not an expert. She is a student, not a scientist, and it is the science that she wants US lawmakers to take heed of.In lieu of an opening testimony, she submitted a copy of the  global warming report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, scientists chosen by the United Nations to help guide world leaders.The report emphasises the dire threat that human-caused global warming poses, along with the climate and economic impacts."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Greta Thunberg tells Congress to listen to scientists","description": "Greta Thunberg tells Congress to listen to scientists","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media ABZzvkj poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests ABZzvkj.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": ldquoI am submitting this report as my testimony because I donrsquot want you to listen to me, Greta told Capitol Hill yesterday. ldquoI want you to listen to the scientists.nd I want you to unite behind the science. And then I want you to take action.Her polite but stern phrasing has underpinned other meetings in Washington, which come ahead of a global climate strike tomorrow, in which scores of students and workers will walk out of schools and officers as world leaders gather in New York for the annual United Nations summit.ldquoPlease save your praise. We donrsquot want it, she told senators on Tuesday. ldquoDonrsquot invite us here to just tell us how inspiring we are without actually doing anything about it, because it doesnrsquot lead to anything.ldquoIf you want advice for what you should do, invite scientists, ask scientists for their expertise. We donrsquot want to be heard. We want the science to be heard.Addressing Congress as a whole, she said: ldquoI know you are trying but just not hard enough. Sorry.Greta appeared before the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Europe, Eurasia, Energy and the Environment and the House Select Committee on the Climate Crisis with three other younger climate activists, Jamie Margolin, Vic Barrett and Benji Backer.Jamie, who is suing the state of Washington over climate change, told the hearing: ldquoPeople who say we have a great future ahead are lying to my face.She pointed out that the destruction already seen in the world from the climate crisis ldquowill get worse and her generation is being left a terrible legacy.ldquoThe government cannot even begin to imagine the size of the political sht that needs to happen to act on the climate crisis, she said. ldquoThe youth are calling for a new era altogether...we only have a few months left to transfer to a renewable energy economy.ldquoPeople call my generation Generation Z aswe are the last generation, but we are not, we are the GND Generation ndash the green new deal generation.In August, Greta captured global attention when she set off from Plymouth on a zero-emissions boat voyage across the Atlantic to avoid using air travel to reach the US. After a -day voyage on a yacht, she arrived in New York City and went on to hold a protest outside the United Nations HQ.During her visit to the US, she has also protested in front of the White House, appeared on Comedy Centralrsquos Daily Show and met with former President Barack Obama, who called the teenager ldquoone of our planetrsquos greatest advocates.ldquoRecognising that her generation will bear the brunt of climate change, shersquos unafraid to push for real action, the former president wrote on Twitter on Tuesday.She is also set to speak at the UN Climate Change Summit later this month.Last week, Greta led a rally outside the White House with dozens of others, chanting: ldquoHey hey, ho ho, climate change has got to go. The protesters, many of them young activists, held a iety of homemade signs, including lsquoMake Earth cool againrsquo and lsquoSave the ice capsrsquo.ldquoIrsquom so incredibly grateful for every single one of you, she told the crowd. ldquoNever give up. We will continue.

And I do take my share of responsibility for that.Mr Cameron told the Today programme he had had to step down following the UKrsquos decision to leave the EU because he would not have been the person to deliver Brexit having campaigned for Remain.Mr Cameron said he had not wanted to resign so quickly after the referendum and ldquohated giving the impression he was running away."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": " uPanicked u Cameron sought Queen us support in Scottish independence campaign","description": " uPanicked u Cameron sought Queen us support in Scottish independence campaign","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media IKWFdwE poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests IKWFdwE.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": He said he would have ldquolacked the credibility a prime minister needs and felt the need to step aside quickly.According to Mr Cameron, Boris Johnson put his own political career before the national interest when he chose to back Brexit during the referendum.Interviewed for the Cameron Years for the BBC, the ex-PM said: ldquoBy fighting for Leave he was taking the romantic, nationalist, Conservative course, hersquod look like a hero, and I donrsquot think he expected for one minute they were going to win.ldquoIn the end, I think, ultimately, he put what was good for his political career ahead of what he actually thought was good for the country.Mr Cameron also suggested Britain has not left the EU yet because Theresa May ignored his advice on Brexit.He told The Times Red Box podcast he had advised Mrs May to pursue a ldquosoft Brexit modelled on Norway, but she ignored him.

title: scottish-elections-fixed-take-place-every-five-years
story: The Scottish Parliamentrsquos Standards, Procedures and Public Appointments Committee announced on Thursday it would explore the possibility of the time between elections in the country being extended from four to five years.:MSPs move to shut down Scottish Government spin on economyThe idea was lodged as part of theScottish ElectionsBill, which was published by the Scottish Government earlier this month.The Scottish ElectionsBill was introduced by @scotgov on Monday. Further details of the Bill are available here: https:t.co WvOziSIF pic viyImPbgEmdash Scottish ParliamentSeptember , Under the Bill, young people would also be able to be added to the electoral register ahead of attaining voting age at .It would mean -year-oldscould apply to be added to the electoral register.Committee convener Bill Kidd said: ldquoThese proposals would permanently change the way national and local elections are run in Scotland.:Neil Mackay: Brexit proves British democracy is alive and wellldquoThe way elections are run are one of the cornerstones of our civic le, so it is important that any changes have a positive and meaningful impact.ldquoThe Bill proposals would allow young people to be added to the electoral register from  and we particularly want to hear from young people about what this change would mean to them and what impact this would have on their access to democracy.

title: snp-minister-scolded-misuse-parliamentary-resources
story: Ivan McKee was ldquoreminded of the rules on political neutrality after a member of the public complained to Holyroodrsquos presiding officer, Ken Macintosh.It followed Mr McKee criticising the UK government and boasting about giving away his own money in a recent newsletter to his constituents in Glasgow Provan.The trade minister said he had been ldquosupporting local residents impacted by Green Deal scheme who had been ldquobadly let down by the UK Government - the fight for justice continues.:Scottish Government to scrap Named Person policyThe millionaire former businessman also used a page and a half of the newsletter to boast about giving away half of his MSPrsquos salary to local firms, schools and clubs.The document, which declared its costs had been ldquomet from Parliamentary resources, should have restricted its content to Mr McKeersquos parliamentary work.In his response to the complainer, Mr Macintosh said Mr McKee had been in the wrong and breached the policy of the Scottish Parliamentary Corporate Body .He wrote: ldquoThe comment in relation to the Green Deal Scheme and the UK Government should not have been included.ldquoUnder the SPCBrsquos policy on Membersrsquo publications, parliamentary funded publications should not include material that criticises any person, political party, the government or other organisation involved in political campaigning. Mr McKee has therefore been reminded of the rules surrounding parliamentary funded publications in relation to this point.Mr Macintosh said it was not a conflict of interest for Mr McKee to publicise his private charitable donations, as private donations were a matter for MSPs as iniduals.But the Presiding Officer went on: ldquoHowever, Mr McKee has been reminded that the purpose of any parliamentary funded publication is to promote his work as an MSP either in the constituency or the Parliament.ldquoHe has agreed that including his private donation is not necessary to advise constituents of the work he is doing with these organisations in his role as an MSP and in future his publications will only show the connection with his work as an MSP and not his actions as a private inidual.:First Ministers Questions: Nicola Sturgeon grilled over Named Person policyGlasgow Labour MSP James Kelly said: ldquoThis is embarrassing for Ivan McKee.ldquoIt is absolutely right that the Presiding Officer and parliamentary authorities have taken him to task for using taxpayersrsquo money for his own political gain.ldquoMaybehe spent more time doing his day job instead of printing political propaganda at the publicrsquos expense Scotlandrsquos economy wouldnrsquot be struggling.A Scottish Parliament spokesperson said: ldquoThe purpose of any parliamentary funded publication is to promote MSPsrsquo work either in the constituency or the Parliament. On review of the newsletter in question, it was found that one item should not have been included.An SNP spokesperson said: ldquoIvan McKees newsletter was approved by the Scottish Parliaments allowances team before it was published."

title: youll-never-first-minister-nicola-sturgeon-tells-richard-leonard
story: She dismissed the chances of Scottish Labour getting into power as a "lost cause" during First Ministers Questions.Ms Sturgeon criticised Mr Leonards "rambling, incoherent series of questions" during their exchange.She said these "just demonstrated why he will never stand here answering First Ministers Questions, because he has zero credibility".The First Minister accused Mr Leonard of having failed to set out how increases in funding for universities and other areas could be met.:SNP minister scolded over misuse of parliamentary resourcesMr Leonard had challenged the SNP leader to give universities a % real-terms increase for teaching and research in next years Scottish budget.The Scottish Labour leader accused her administration of presiding over the "managed decline" of Scotlands universities sector.She responded: "Richard Leonard has made a specic request today for a % real-terms increase in funding for universities. So I will make my usual offer to him."As I keep reminding him, we allocate all of the Scottish Government budget every year so it is fully allocated to our hospitals, schools, local government services, to universities, to colleges."If Richard Leonard wants a % increase for universities on top of the increases he calls for for local government and everything  we are responsible for, then bring forward where in the Scottish budget you think we should make the reductions."Ive asked Richard Leonard to do this on countless occasions now, he hasnt once come forward with any ideas. Maybe today will be dferent, the door is open, as always."The Labour leader said as it was First Ministers Questions it was for him to ask the questions."I am asking you questions about your record on higher education," he told Ms Sturgeon."I didnt hear an answer to my question."He challenged her again on the issue, saying "Under your watch we have witnessed funding decreasing ,a system declining, all because your government is deprioritising higher education.":First Ministers Questions: Nicola Sturgeon grilled over Named Person policyMs Sturgeon said: "If Richard Leonard wants us to spend more on any particular area then we have to spend less on another area. That is simple arithmetic."If Richard Leonard wants to be taken seriously - not as a potential Government, I think that is long gone as a lost cause - buthe wants to be taken seriously even as an opposition he has to bring forward those proposals."Im still waiting for him to bring forward anything with any credibility - and until he does Labour and Richard Leonard will have zero credibility out there amongst the Scottish electorate."

title: palaces-displeasure-david-camerons-indiscretion-queen-comments
story: The former prime minister acknowledged he had said ldquoperhaps a little bit too much about his dealings with the monarch, who is meant to remain above the political fray.:David Cameron: I did not ask the Queen to do lsquoanything improperrsquo during Scottish independence campaignMr Cameron sought support from the Queen after a poll predicting a Yes victory ldquopanicked him.He told a BBC documentary he made contact with Buckingham Palace officials in , suggesting the monarch could ldquoraise an eyebrow in the close-fought campaign.A few days before the referendum in September , the Queen told a well-wisher in Aberdeenshire that she hoped ldquopeople would think very carefully about the future.In an attempt to play down the row over his revelation, Mr Cameron later insisted he did not ask the Queen to do ldquoanything improper during the referendum on Scottish independence.The former prime minister ndash who has been carrying out a media blitz to promote his memoirs ndashtold BBC Radio rsquos Today programme: ldquoI never asked for anything improper to be said or done.He added: ldquoI donrsquot want to say anything more about this, Irsquom sure some people would think ndash possibly even me ndash that I have already said perhaps a little bit too much.He had previously told the BBC: ldquoI remember conversations I had with my private secretary and he had with the Queenrsquos private secretary and I had with the Queenrsquos private secretary, not asking for anything that would be in any way improper or unconstitutional, but just a raising of the eyebrow, even, you know, a quarter of an inch, we thought would make a dference.The BBC quoted an unnamed source as saying Mr Cameronrsquos remarks had led to ldquoan amount of displeasure in Buckingham Palace.:David Cameron secretly asked the Queen to back the Union in the  Scottish independence campaignThe source said that ldquoit serves no onersquos interests for conversations between the prime minister and the Queen to be made public and ldquoit makes it very hard for the relationship to thrive.The Queenrsquos dealings with the current Prime Minister are also in the spotlight after Boris Johnson told her to order the suspension of Parliament ndash which is the subject of a legal battle at the Supreme Court.Mr Cameron has a history of indiscretion in his dealings with the monarch.He admitted that talking about her ldquopurring down the line to him after the No victory in the Scottish referendum had been a ldquoterrible mistake.

title: four-loyalist-marches-get-glasgow-city-council-go-ahead-weekend
story: Councilbosses have taken a decision to allowthe events after talks with policeFour marches are due to take place on Saturday, all by loyalist organisations, with a notice to parade by the West ofScotlandBand Alliancewithdrawn.Assistant chief constable Bernard Higgins said: "Our view is thatprocessions were banned, some form of protest and disorder could still take place and the policing profile for Saturday would therefore be similar."If the processions go ahead it will allow us to continue to engage with known organsiers to ensure balanced rights were upheld and to police the events under the conditions agreed by the council."I need to appeal to people who plan on taking part in processions or counter protests to do so peacefully.Statement from ACC Bernard Higgins following @GlasgowCC announcement that four public processions due to take place in Glasgow on Saturday are expected to go ahead - pic eKuEJmdrE:Glasgow MSP calls for reduction in lsquosectarianrsquo marches"We will have a range of policing resources, including a range of specialist assets, in attendance and will take any necessary action against anyone causing disruption."The decision to amend the route or the timing, or to prohibit any processions is a matter for the relevant local authority."Police Scotland is required to assist councils to make informed decisions by making appropraite representations on notications which could potentially signicantly risk public safety, disorder, damage to property or disruption to the le ofthe community."Around  people are expected to take part in a procession coordinated byPride of Govan flute band, starting on Craigton Road on Saturday morning.TheIndependent Loyal Orange Order, with  followers, are due to walk through George Square after leaving Blythswood Square and pass thousands of Scottish Independence supporters at a Hope Over Fear rally.Organisers have previously said they would be bitterlydisappointedthey were stopped from marching this weekend.Other marches, by Drumchapel Orange  Purple Districtand Springburn Campsie Apprentice Boys of Derry, are set to attract a total of around  and  marches respectively in local areas.: In full: The  marches planned for Glasgow city centreBosses took the previously unprecedented stepfollowing advice from Police Scotland andtwo weekends of violence, with large protests against marches across the city.Over the past week, the council have received support for their decision, including from First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and Justice Secretary Humza Yousaf, as well as the Church of Scotland.However, on Saturday a protest was held by a number of Protestant and loyalist groups in the citys George Square against the ban.Talks were reportedly held about future marches between loyal order groups and council officials, as well as police, earlier this week.

title: sturgeon-urged-come-clean-private-email-use
story: The First Minister appeared taken aback when Tory MP Donald Cameron put the question to her at FMQs.As opposition MSPs urged her to reply ldquoYes or No, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoRightly or wrongly, most of my conduct of Government business is on paper. I receive paper boxes, not email boxes, and I make handwritten notes. We will continue to respond to Freedom of Information requests about email correspondence on any particular issue.Her official spokesman later claimed Ms Sturgeon didnrsquot use her government email account, relying on her private office instead, and did no ldquosubstantive government business using other email accounts.Mr Cameron sits on the Holyrood committee probing Ms Sturgeonrsquos contacts with former First Minister Alex Salmond last year, while he was being investigated by her officials over alleged sexual misconduct in office.He said Ms Sturgeonrsquos failure to answer a simple yes-no questions was simply not good enough.He said: ldquoSurely everyone can agree that using private emails to conduct government business is wrong. If it has happened, it only begs the question as to what the First Minister has to hide. The SNP Government already has a desperate record when it comes to transparency. I hope she will do the right thing and make her position clear over the coming days.

title: four fifths of our carbon footprint is down to our consumption habit
story: Businesses that don#t act now to meet growing public pressure to tackle the global climate emergency risk being left behind.That’s the warning from Zero Waste Scotland which says organisations must do more and examine how they produce, consume and dispose of everyday items just to stay in the race – and urges them to embrace the circular economy.Zero Waste Scotland stresses firms achieving a more sustainable way of working would deliver huge results in cutting Scotland’s carbon footprint. This is because four fths of Scotland’s carbon footprint is generated through the heat and energy required to grow, make, process, transport and provide materials that are often tossed aside at the end of their le.Only by considering how to make products with less reliance on raw materials, and by remaking items at the end of their original le into goods that can be used time and again, will businesses be able to signicantly reduce global emissions.Iain Gulland, chief executive of Zero Waste Scotland, who launched the organisation’s corporate plan before an auduence of business leaders last week, said: “We must radically change the way we think about and consume our goods and materials, and we must do that now.” “Too many businesses assume that reducing the cost to the planet means increasing costs for them. “But as we have and will continue to make clear, the opportunities are plentul, with massive savings to be made. “The current way of working cannot continue in the years ahead and successfully adopting a circular economy approach is the only long-term option.”Everything has value and in a circular economy nothing should be wasted. In simple terms, it can be explained as ‘make, use, remake’ as opposed to ‘make, use, dispose’. The ultimate goal is to maintain and improve our quality of le, while simultaneously reducing our material consumption and, by extension, our impact on the planet.Mr Gulland added: “Many Scottish firms are already leading the way, with our help, changing how they design and trade goods to keep materials in use for as long as possible to maximise their value. “Successful circular economy enterprises range from refurbishing computers and upcycling furniture to producing sustainable animal feed using waste generated by our world-famous whisky industry.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.kincardineshireobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Felicitasis just one of the many children supported by Marys Meals."   is just one of the many children supported by Marys Meals." title: call for shops to close on new year s day
story: The shopworkers# trade union is urging all MSPs to back a motion calling for the closure of large shops in New Year#s Day.A survey of Scottish retail staff by the union Usdaw shows overwhelming support for the closure of stores on January .And the union is now calling on all MSPs to support the motion tabled by Jackie Baillie MSP in the Scottish Parliament seeking to ensure shop workers can enjoy some time off at New Year.The survey of more than  shop workers revealed:•  per cent believed stores should close on New Year’s Day, with  per cent saying they should also close on January .• Three quarters feel they spend too little time with friends and family over New Year.•  per cent have come under pressure to work on New Year’s Day or January .• Four in ten don’t receive any premium pay for working on New Year’s Day.•  per cent are not happy to work on New Year’s Day or January .Stewart Forrest, Usdaw’s Scottish isional officer, said: “This survey clearly demonstrates the strength feeling among our members. “We have written to all MSPs asking them to support Jackie Baillie’s motion calling for a decent break at New Year after the busy Christmas period.“I have also written to the Scottish Retail Consortium urging them to reconsider their opposition to large stores closing on New Year’s Day.”Mr Forrest stressed the union was fully supportive of efforts to revitalise our high streets as the livelihoods of its members depended on a thriving retail sector.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.kirkintilloch-herald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Failing to get young pets vaccinated leaves them exposed to fatal diseases." She added: “Christmas and New Year is a time which should be spent with family, and there are few days in the year when families are off at the same time. “The results of Usdaw’s survey show that the overwhelming majority of respondents want to spend more time with their families during Christmas and New Year.“I hope all of my MSP colleagues will recognise that everyone deserves a day off for New Year and will support the motion that I have tabled in the Scottish Parliament.”

title: a waste of money oic homes in on refuse issues
story: Should Orkney deal with its own rubbish rather than paying hundreds of thousands of pounds annually to ship it where That was the question on the lips of several councillors on Tuesday, as they faced a £, overspend in Orkney Islands Council#s waste disposal budget.With the council spending a total of £,, on dumping refuse in the past year, on top of £, to collect it, members of the OIC development and infrastructure committee are keen to find a solution — either by lobbying the Scottish Government for more funding, or by investing in a method of dealing with waste in-house.#We need to find a local solution,# said Kirkwall West and Orphir councillor Leslie Manson, who pointed out that the shipping of waste also contradicted anti-climate change policies.#If we cannot deal with refuse, we have to use lots of fossil fuel to get it where.#He later added: #We have to pay money to ship it where it gets buried for a while. We need to deal with our waste responsibility at home.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. title: gas canisters safe disposal reminder
story: Orkney Islands Council is reminding the public about the dangers of incorrectly disposing of gas canisters.This comes as some were found incorrectly disposed of in metal can recycling skips at Hatston Household Waste Recycling Centreon Monday.Environmental services facilities manager for Orkney Islands Council, Jonathan Walters, said: “Never place a gas bottle in with your recycling at the kerbside or at a  Household Waste Recycling Centre , as they could explode when metal cans are crushed to be sent for re-processing and potentially cause serious injury.#There have been recent examples of fires at HWRCs in the UK as a result of people placing metal gas canisters in metal recycling skips”.It is advised toempty gas bottles to the retailer or your original supplier, rather than a HWRC. They will then be collected and refilled for re-use.  Camping gas bottles cannot be recycled however they must not be placed in your general waste bin or a skip.#Return your empty bottles to the retailer or your original supplierthey offer a take back scheme. Failing that, take your empty canisters to a staffed HWRCas hazardous waste to ensure they are disposed of safely.#If you have gas canisters or bottles for disposal or are still unsure, you can contact the Waste Team at Orkney Islands Council on:  Ext  or recycling@orkney.gov.ukcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
